List of genes : <<< ADH1C,UGT2B15,UGT1A4,CYP2D6,UGT1A9,GSTK1,ADH6,GSTP1,UGT2B4,CYP2B6,MGST1,UGT1A1,GSTT2,GSTM4 >>>
List of compounds : <<< alpha-(1,2-Dihydroxyethyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-7-hydroxy-9-methoxy-3,4-dioxocyclopenta[c][1]benzopyran-6-acetaldehyde,Aflatoxin B1exo-8,9-epoxide-GSH,Chloral hydrate,9-Hydroxybenzo[a]pyrene,Aflatoxin B1-endo-8,9-epoxide,7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene,1,4-Naphthoquinone,Bromobenzene,Trichloroethanol glucuronide,(1S)-Hydroxy-(2S)-glutathionyl-1,2-dihydronaphthalene,Aflatoxin B1 diol,1-Nitro-5-glutathionyl-6-hydroxy-5,6-dihydronaphthalene,1-(Methylnitrosoamino)-4-(3-pyridinyl)-1,4-butanediol,N-Hydroxy-1-aminonaphthalene >>>

The analysis of the provided gene and compound lists suggests that the Metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450 pathway is significantly involved in the condition under investigation. This conclusion is supported by the presence of several key genes associated with this pathway, including CYP2D6, CYP2B6, UGT1A1, UGT1A4, UGT1A9, UGT2B15, and UGT2B4. These genes encode enzymes responsible for metabolizing various xenobiotics, which are foreign substances introduced into the body. The detected compounds, such as Aflatoxin B1exo-8,9-epoxide-GSH, Aflatoxin B1-endo-8,9-epoxide, and 1-Nitro-5-glutathionyl-6-hydroxy-5,6-dihydronaphthalene, are also known metabolites or products of cytochrome P450 enzymes, further corroborating the involvement of this pathway.

target: Metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450

messages.content:
List of genes : <<< ALDH3B1,GOT1,AOC3,GOT2,PAH,ALDH3B2,MAOA,MAOB,HPD,IL4I1,GOT1L1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-(1,2-Epoxy-1,2-dihydrophenyl)acetyl-CoA,N-Acetyl-L-phenylalanine,2-Hydroxyphenylacetate,Phenylacetylglutamine,Acetyl-CoA,(3S)-3-Hydroxyadipyl-CoA,Succinate,3-(2,3-Dihydroxyphenyl)propanoate,Phenylpyruvate,D-Phenylalanine,2-Hydroxy-3-phenylpropenoate,3-Oxoadipyl-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified from the provided data is Phenylalanine metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alteration of several key genes and compounds associated with this pathway.

Genes such as PAH (Phenylalanine Hydroxylase), GOT1 and GOT2 (Glutamic-Oxaloacetic Transaminase 1 and 2), and IL4I1 (Interleukin 4 Induced 1) are directly involved in the phenylalanine metabolism pathway. The presence of MAOA and MAOB (Monoamine Oxidase A and B) also suggests a role in phenylalanine metabolism as these enzymes are involved in the catabolism of phenylalanine derivatives.

The list of compounds further supports this conclusion. Compounds like D-Phenylalanine, N-Acetyl-L-phenylalanine, Phenylpyruvate, and Phenylacetylglutamine are direct intermediates in the phenylalanine metabolism pathway. The presence of 2-(1,2-Epoxy-1,2-dihydrophenyl)acetyl-CoA, 2-Hydroxyphenylacetate, 3-(2,3-Dihydroxyphenyl)propanoate, and 2-Hydroxy-3-phenylpropenoate, which are derivatives of phenylalanine, also point towards the involvement of the phenylalanine metabolism pathway.

List of genes : <<< GLUL,CAT,HYI,AGXT,ACAT2,HAO1,GRHPR,MCEE,ACSS2,ACAT1,SHMT2,PCCA,GLYCTK,SHMT1,MMUT,DLD,CS,GLDC,MDH2,MDH1,ACSS1,AFMID,HOGA1,HAO2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Glyoxylate,L-Glutamate,Isocitrate,(R)-Methylmalonyl-CoA,Pyruvate,2-Hydroxy-3-oxosuccinate,cis-Aconitate,(2S)-Methylsuccinyl-CoA,3-Phospho-D-glycerate,Mesaconate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism. This conclusion is based on the alterations in the genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes GLUL, CAT, AGXT, ACAT2, HAO1, GRHPR, MCEE, ACSS2, ACSS1, and DLD, along with the compounds Glyoxylate, L-Glutamate, Isocitrate, (R)-Methylmalonyl-CoA, 2-Hydroxy-3-oxosuccinate, cis-Aconitate, (2S)-Methylsuccinyl-CoA, and 3-Phospho-D-glycerate, are all directly or indirectly involved in this pathway. For instance, GLUL is involved in glutamate metabolism, ACAT2 and DLD in the citrate cycle, and HAO1 and GRHPR in glyoxylate metabolism. The presence of compounds like Glyoxylate and Isocitrate further supports this conclusion.

List of genes : <<< CYP2C8,PLA2G6,PLA2G4D,PLA2G12B,PLA2G10,PLA2G2A,PLA2G5,PLB1,PLA2G3,PLA2G12A,CYP2J2,CYP3A4,PLA2G4C,PLA2G4F,ALOX15,PLA2G4A,PLA2G1B,PLA2G2C >>>
List of compounds : <<< Linoleate,Phosphatidylcholine,Arachidonate,12,13-Epoxy-9-hydroxy-10-octadecenoate,9(10)-EpOME,(6Z,9Z,12Z)-Octadecatrienoic acid,9,12,13-TriHOME,9-OxoODE,12,13-DHOME,9(S)-HPODE,8(R)-HPODE,9,10-Dihydroxy-12,13-epoxyoctadecanoate,9,10,13-TriHOME,(9Z,11E)-12-[(1E)-Hex-1-en-1-yloxy]dodeca-9,11-dienoic acid,5S,8R-DiHODE,(8E,10R,12Z)-10-Hydroperoxy-8,12-octadecadienoate,9,12,13-TriHOME,12(13)-EpOME,Crepenynate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Linoleic Acid Metabolism. This is supported by the alteration of numerous genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. The genes CYP2C8, CYP2J2, and CYP3A4 code for enzymes that metabolize linoleic acid and related compounds. The PLA2G family of genes encode phospholipases, which release linoleic acid from phospholipids. The ALOX15 gene encodes an enzyme that oxygenates linoleic acid, leading to the production of various hydroxy and epoxy fatty acids, several of which were altered in this experiment, such as Linoleate, Arachidonate, 12,13-Epoxy-9-hydroxy-10-octadecenoate, and 9(10)-EpOME. Furthermore, the presence of compounds like 9,12,13-TriHOME, 9-OxoODE, and 12(13)-EpOME, which are downstream metabolites in the linoleic acid metabolism pathway, further supports this identification.

List of genes : <<< AK9,DGUOK,ENTPD8,NT5C3B,ADSS2,NT5DC4,ADK,ADA2,DCTD,PNP,TYMS,AK3,AK2,ENPP3,TYMP,ASMTL,NUDT16,NT5C1B,DUT,NT5C,AK4,CMPK1,CTPS1,RRM1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Uridine,L-Glutamine >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is nucleotide metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alteration of multiple genes involved in nucleotide biosynthesis, degradation, and salvage pathways. Genes such as AK9, DGUOK, ENTPD8, NT5C3B, ADSS2, NT5DC4, ADK, ADA2, DCTD, PNP, TYMS, AK3, AK2, ENPP3, TYMP, ASMTL, NUDT16, NT5C1B, DUT, NT5C, AK4, CMPK1, CTPS1, and RRM1 are all involved in nucleotide metabolism. Additionally, the altered compounds, Uridine and L-Glutamine, are also integral to nucleotide metabolism. Uridine is a pyrimidine nucleotide, and L-Glutamine is a crucial amino acid for nucleotide synthesis. Therefore, the alteration of these genes and compounds strongly suggests that nucleotide metabolism is a key pathway involved in the specific condition under investigation.

List of genes : <<< PLCH1,CDIPT,PLCD1,PI4KB,ALDH6A1,ITPKA,PIP5K1A,IMPA1,INPP5K,INPP4A,IMPA2,PIP5K1C,INPP5F,ITPK1,PLCB1,PI4K2B,INPP5J,PLCE1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 1-Phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 3,5-bisphosphate,D-Bornesitol,D-myo-Inositol 3,4-bisphosphate,Phytic acid,L-Bornesitol,2,4,6/3,5-Pentahydroxycyclohexanone,D-myo-Inositol 1,2,4,5,6-pentakisphosphate,Acetyl-CoA,1D-myo-Inositol 1,4,5,6-tetrakisphosphate,2-Deoxy-5-keto-D-gluconic acid 6-phosphate,Inositol 1,2,3,5,6-pentakisphosphate,1D-myo-Inositol 3-phosphate,2-Deoxy-5-keto-D-gluconic acid,5-Dehydro-L-gluconate,1-Keto-D-chiro-inositol,5-Deoxy-D-glucuronate,D-Glucuronate,D-Tagaturonate,1D-chiro-Inositol,D-Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate,1-Phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 3-phosphate,D-Glucose 6-phosphate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Inositol phosphate metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in multiple genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes PLCH1, CDIPT, PLCD1, PI4KB, ALDH6A1, ITPKA, PIP5K1A, IMPA1, INPP5K, INPP4A, IMPA2, PIP5K1C, INPP5F, ITPK1, PLCB1, PI4K2B, INPP5J, and PLCE1 are all involved in the synthesis, dephosphorylation, and signaling of inositol phosphates. Similarly, the compounds 1-Phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 3,5-bisphosphate, D-Bornesitol, D-myo-Inositol 3,4-bisphosphate, Phytic acid, L-Bornesitol, 2,4,6/3,5-Pentahydroxycyclohexanone, D-myo-Inositol 1,2,4,5,6-pentakisphosphate, Acetyl-CoA, 1D-myo-Inositol 1,4,5,6-tetrakisphosphate, 2-Deoxy-5-keto-D-gluconic acid 6-phosphate, Inositol 1,2,3,5,6-pentakisphosphate, 1D-myo-Inositol 3-phosphate, 2-Deoxy-5-keto-D-gluconic acid, 5-Dehydro-L-gluconate, 1-Keto-D-chiro-inositol, 5-Deoxy-D-glucuronate, D-Glucuronate, D-Tagaturonate, 1D-chiro-Inositol, D-Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, 1-Phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 3-phosphate, and D-Glucose 6-phosphate are all intermediates or products of the Inositol phosphate metabolism pathway. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the Inositol phosphate metabolism pathway is involved in the specific condition being studied.

List of genes : <<< ASL,PFKL,TKTL1,PGAM1,ARG1,PKM,PGAM2,PFKM,ALDOA,RPIA,PSAT1,ARG2,MAT2A,PKLR,ENO2,PYCR1,ASNS,BCAT2,MTR,ABHD14A-ACY1,RPE,GPT,PGK2,ENO4,ASS1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-Oxoadipate,L-Glutamate 5-semialdehyde,D-Fructose 6-phosphate,L-Arginine,2-Oxoglutarate,L-Asparagine,5-(5-Phospho-D-ribosylaminoformimino)-1-(5-phosphoribosyl)-imidazole-4-carboxamide,D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate,2-Oxobutanoate,N-Acetyl-L-glutamate,5-O-(1-Carboxyvinyl)-3-phosphoshikimate,Citrate,O-Succinyl-L-homoserine,Chorismate,N-Succinyl-2-L-amino-6-oxoheptanedioate,alpha-Isopropylmalate,Phosphoribosyl-AMP,(R)-2-Methylmalate,(2R,3S)-3-Isopropylmalate,L-Isoleucine,3-Phospho-D-glyceroyl phosphate,L-Aspartate,L-Serine,L-Histidine,O-Acetyl-L-serine >>>

The metabolic pathway identified based on the altered genes and compounds is the biosynthesis of amino acids. This is supported by the presence of several genes involved in amino acid metabolism, such as ARG1, ARG2, ASS1, and ASNS, which are associated with arginine and asparagine biosynthesis. The compound L-Arginine, a key intermediate in this pathway, was also found to be altered. Additionally, other genes like MAT2A, involved in the biosynthesis of S-adenosylmethionine, a universal methyl donor, and BCAT2, involved in branched-chain amino acid metabolism, further support this identification. The altered compounds such as L-Glutamate 5-semialdehyde, 5-O-(1-Carboxyvinyl)-3-phosphoshikimate, O-Succinyl-L-homoserine, Chorismate, and N-Succinyl-2-L-amino-6-oxoheptanedioate are also intermediates in amino acid biosynthesis, providing further evidence for this pathway's involvement.

List of genes : <<< RFK,ACP5,BLVRB >>>
List of compounds : <<< Ribitol,Prenol,2,5-Diamino-6-(5-phospho-D-ribosylamino)pyrimidin-4(3H)-one,Riboflavin,2-Amino-5-formylamino-6-(5-phospho-D-ribosylamino)pyrimidin-4(3H)-one,2,5-Diamino-6-(5-phospho-D-ribitylamino)pyrimidin-4(3H)-one,5-Amino-6-(5'-phosphoribosylamino)uracil,L-3,4-Dihydroxybutan-2-one 4-phosphate,D-Ribulose 5-phosphate,5-Amino-6-(1-D-ribitylamino)uracil,FMN,5-Amino-6-(5'-phospho-D-ribitylamino)uracil,Dimethylallyl phosphate,GTP,Reduced riboflavin,Lumichrome,Dimethylbenzimidazole,Reduced FMN >>>

The analysis of the provided genes and compounds suggests that the Riboflavin metabolism pathway is significantly altered in the compared conditions. The presence of genes such as RFK (Riboflavin kinase), which is a key enzyme in the conversion of riboflavin to FMN (flavin mononucleotide), supports this conclusion. The altered compounds, including Riboflavin, FMN, and their reduced forms, as well as intermediates like 2,5-Diamino-6-(5-phospho-D-ribosylamino)pyrimidin-4(3H)-one, further substantiate the involvement of this pathway. Additionally, the presence of ACP5 (Acid Phosphatase 5), which can hydrolyze a variety of phosphate esters, and BLVRB (Biliverdin reductase B), which is involved in heme catabolism, could suggest potential crosstalk with other metabolic pathways. However, based on the provided information, the primary pathway affected appears to be Riboflavin metabolism.

List of genes : <<< TAT,VKORC1L1,COQ3,COQ6,COQ2,GGCX,HPD,NQO1,COQ7,VKORC1,COQ5 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 6-Amino-6-deoxyfutalosine,all-trans-Polyprenyl diphosphate,Dehypoxanthine futalosine,Geranyl diphosphate,Demethylmenaquinol,2-Methyl-6-phytylquinol >>>

The metabolic pathway identified from the given experiment is the "Ubiquinone and other terpenoid-quinone biosynthesis" pathway. This identification is based on the alterations in several genes and compounds that are directly involved in this pathway.

The genes COQ2, COQ3, COQ5, COQ6, and COQ7 are all part of the ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway, which is responsible for the production of coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10), a vital component for electron transport in the mitochondria. The alterations in these genes could impact the production of CoQ10 and affect cellular energy production.

The presence of compounds such as all-trans-Polyprenyl diphosphate, Geranyl diphosphate, and Demethylmenaquinol also supports this identification. These are intermediates in the terpenoid-quinone biosynthesis pathway, further indicating that this pathway is affected in the given condition.

The alterations in other genes like TAT, VKORC1L1, GGCX, HPD, and NQO1, as well as the presence of compounds like 6-Amino-6-deoxyfutalosine, Dehypoxanthine futalosine, and 2-Methyl-6-phytylquinol, may be related to other metabolic pathways or could be secondary effects due to the disruption of the ubiquinone biosynthesis pathway.

List of genes : <<< PDHA1,DHTKD1,GCSH,PDHA2,OGDH,ACSM1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Dihydrolipoylprotein,Dihydrolipoyl-AMP,CO2,5,10-Methylenetetrahydrofolate,Thiamin diphosphate,Octanoyl-[acp],[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue (2-methylpropanoyl)transferase] S-(2-methylpropanoyl)dihydrolipoyllysine,Enzyme N6-(lipoyl)lysine,Ammonia >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Lipoic Acid Metabolism pathway. This is supported by the alteration of multiple genes directly involved in this pathway, including PDHA1, PDHA2, DHTKD1, and OGDH, which are components of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex and the 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, both of which require lipoic acid for their function. The alteration of GCSH, which is involved in the synthesis of glutathione, a compound that can interact with lipoic acid, also supports this finding. Furthermore, the presence of altered compounds such as Dihydrolipoylprotein, Dihydrolipoyl-AMP, and Enzyme N6-(lipoyl)lysine, which are direct products or intermediates of the lipoic acid metabolism pathway, further confirm this identification.

List of genes : <<< DLAT,PGM1,LDHAL6A,PFKL,PGAM4,ALDH3B2,FBP2,ALDH3A1,ENO2,HK2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< D-Glucose,Ethanol,2,3-Bisphospho-D-glycerate,Acetyl-CoA,Thiamin diphosphate,beta-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,D-Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate,Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine,(S)-Lactate,D-Fructose 6-phosphate,3-Phospho-D-glycerate,2-(alpha-Hydroxyethyl)thiamine diphosphate,alpha-D-Glucose,alpha-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,2-Phospho-D-glycerate,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine,Arbutin,Acetate,D-Glucose 1-phosphate,D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate,beta-D-Glucose,Phosphoenolpyruvate,Salicin 6-phosphate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified based on the altered genes and compounds is Glycolysis/Gluconeogenesis. This conclusion is supported by the presence of multiple genes directly involved in this pathway, such as PGM1, PFKL, PGAM4, ENO2, and HK2. The compounds D-Glucose, D-Fructose 6-phosphate, beta-D-Glucose 6-phosphate, D-Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, 3-Phospho-D-glycerate, 2-Phospho-D-glycerate, and Phosphoenolpyruvate are key intermediates in this pathway. Additionally, the presence of Acetyl-CoA and Acetate suggests involvement of pyruvate metabolism, which is closely linked to Glycolysis/Gluconeogenesis. The altered genes DLAT, LDHAL6A, ALDH3B2, ALDH3A1, and FBP2, while not directly in the pathway, are involved in related metabolic processes, further supporting the identification of Glycolysis/Gluconeogenesis as the affected pathway.

List of genes : <<< ST3GAL5,ST8SIA5,ST3GAL1,ST6GALNAC6,HEXA,ST6GALNAC4 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Lactosylceramide,GM2,GA1,GD1a,GQ1b,GM2alpha,GT1b,GD2,Fucosyl-GM1,9-O-Acetylated GD3,GT1aalpha,GD1b,GT1c,GM3,9-O-Acetylated GT3,N-Acetylgalactosaminyl GM1b,GD1a,GQ1balpha,GT2,GM1b >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Glycosphingolipid biosynthesis - ganglio series. This pathway was suggested based on the alterations in multiple genes and compounds associated with it. The genes ST3GAL5, ST8SIA5, ST3GAL1, ST6GALNAC6, HEXA, and ST6GALNAC4 are all involved in the synthesis of gangliosides, complex glycosphingolipids found in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane. The altered compounds, including Lactosylceramide, GM2, GA1, GD1a, GQ1b, GM2alpha, GT1b, GD2, Fucosyl-GM1, 9-O-Acetylated GD3, GT1aalpha, GD1b, GT1c, GM3, 9-O-Acetylated GT3, N-Acetylgalactosaminyl GM1b, GD1a, GQ1balpha, GT2, and GM1b, are all intermediates or end products of this pathway. Therefore, the alterations in these genes and compounds suggest that the Glycosphingolipid biosynthesis - ganglio series pathway is involved in the specific condition being studied.

List of genes : <<< MAOA,AGMAT,GATM,P4HA3,CKMT1A >>>
List of compounds : <<< 1,3-Diaminopropane,4-(L-gamma-Glutamylamino)butanoate,Feruloyl-CoA,4-Aminobutyraldehyde,Feruloylputrescine,Glyoxylate,Agmatine,S-Adenosylmethioninamine,N2-Succinyl-L-ornithine,4-Guanidinobutanoate,L-Glutamate,N-Carbamoylputrescine,N-Succinyl-L-glutamate 5-semialdehyde,(4R)-4-Hydroxy-2-oxoglutarate,5-Guanidino-2-oxopentanoate,4-Guanidinobutanamide,N-Acetyl-L-glutamate 5-semialdehyde,Pyruvate,N-Methylhydantoin,L-Glutamyl 5-phosphate,S-Adenosyl-L-methionine,N1-[(S)-3-amino-3-carboxypropyl]agmatine,N2-Succinyl-L-arginine,trans-3-Hydroxy-L-proline >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Arginine and Proline Metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alteration of several key genes and compounds involved in this pathway. The genes MAOA, AGMAT, and GATM are associated with the metabolism of amino acids, particularly arginine and proline. The presence of compounds such as Agmatine, N2-Succinyl-L-ornithine, L-Glutamate, and N2-Succinyl-L-arginine further corroborate this finding. These compounds are intermediates or products of the Arginine and Proline Metabolism pathway. Additionally, the presence of compounds like Feruloyl-CoA and Glyoxylate, which are involved in other metabolic pathways, suggest possible cross-talk or regulation between these pathways and Arginine and Proline Metabolism.

List of genes : <<< GCK,HK2,HKDC1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2'-Deamino-2'-hydroxyneamine,2-Deoxy-scyllo-inosamine,Gentamicin C2b,6''-O-Carbamoylkanamycin A,UDP-kanosamine,6'-Oxokanamycin X,Kanamycin C,Lividamine >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the "Neomycin, kanamycin, and gentamicin biosynthesis" pathway. This is supported by the alterations in several genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes GCK, HK2, and HKDC1 are involved in glycolysis, a pathway that provides precursors for amino sugar synthesis, which is a crucial step in the biosynthesis of these antibiotics. The presence of compounds such as 2-Deoxy-scyllo-inosamine, UDP-kanosamine, and Kanamycin C further supports this, as they are intermediates or end products of this pathway. The altered compounds 2'-Deamino-2'-hydroxyneamine, Gentamicin C2b, 6''-O-Carbamoylkanamycin A, 6'-Oxokanamycin X, and Lividamine are also derivatives or precursors in this biosynthetic pathway, suggesting a disruption or alteration in this metabolic process.

List of genes : <<< ALDH6A1,ALDH3B1,ALDH3A2,AOC3,ALDH9A1,SMOX,ECHS1,CNDP1,ALDH3B2,ACOX3,ALDH1B1,ALDH3A1,DPYS,DPYD,HADHA,UPB1,CSAD,CARNS1,EHHADH >>>
List of compounds : <<< beta-Alanyl-N(pi)-methyl-L-histidine,Uracil,beta-Alanine,3-Aminopropiononitrile,L-Aspartate,3-Hydroxypropanoate,5,6-Dihydrouracil,Pantothenate,Spermidine,Malonyl-CoA,Spermine,3-Oxopropanoate,beta-Nitropropanoate,N-Acetyl-beta-alanine,4-Aminobutanoate,Propenoyl-CoA,Acetyl-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the beta-Alanine metabolism pathway. This conclusion is supported by the significant alterations observed in multiple genes and compounds associated with this pathway. Genes such as ALDH3B1, ALDH3A2, ALDH3B2, and ALDH1B1, which are involved in the conversion of beta-Alanine to malonic semialdehyde, were found to be altered. Similarly, the compound beta-Alanine itself, along with its derivatives like N-Acetyl-beta-alanine and 3-Hydroxypropanoate, were also altered. The presence of compounds like 3-Aminopropiononitrile, a known inhibitor of beta-Alanine metabolism, further strengthens this conclusion. Therefore, the data strongly suggests that the beta-Alanine metabolism pathway is significantly involved in the observed conditions.

List of genes : <<< ADH4,FH,GRHPR,ALDH9A1,ACYP1,ACOT12,PDHB,MDH2,ADH5,LDHAL6A,LDHA,GLO1,ADH1B,ACACB,DLAT,LDHC,ALDH2,ME1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Oxaloacetate,(R)-Lactate,2-(alpha-Hydroxyethyl)thiamine diphosphate,Phosphoenolpyruvate,2-Hydroxyethylenedicarboxylate,(S)-Lactaldehyde,(S)-Malate,Ethanol,Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine,Malonyl-CoA,Fumarate,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine,2-Propylmalate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Pyruvate metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alteration of several genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. For instance, genes such as LDHA and LDHC, which encode lactate dehydrogenases responsible for converting pyruvate to lactate, are present. The presence of (R)-Lactate and (S)-Lactaldehyde, intermediates in this process, further supports this. Additionally, genes like PDHB and MDH2, involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and then to citrate in the TCA cycle, are altered. The presence of compounds such as Oxaloacetate, Malate, and Fumarate, intermediates in the TCA cycle, also aligns with this pathway. Furthermore, the alteration of genes like ADH4, ADH5, and ADH1B, which are involved in ethanol metabolism, a branch of pyruvate metabolism, and the presence of Ethanol, provide additional evidence. Therefore, the data strongly suggests that Pyruvate metabolism is the primary pathway affected in this condition.

List of genes : <<< CAD,DDO,GOT1,GLUD1,ALDH5A1,GLS2,ASPA,GPT,ADSL,IL4I1,GOT1L1,ASS1,RIMKLA,GFPT1,GAD2,GLUL,ASNS,PPAT >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-Oxoglutaramate,N-Acetyl-L-aspartate,L-Asparagine,Carbamoyl phosphate,Fumarate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Alanine, Aspartate and Glutamate metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in multiple genes and compounds involved in this metabolic process. For instance, the genes CAD, GOT1, GLUD1, GLS2, and GPT are directly involved in this pathway. The compound 2-Oxoglutaramate is a derivative of 2-Oxoglutarate, a key molecule in this pathway, while L-Asparagine and Carbamoyl phosphate are closely linked to aspartate and glutamate metabolism respectively. The alterations in these genes and compounds therefore suggest perturbations in this metabolic pathway.

List of genes : <<< GOT2,IL4I1,GOT1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-Dehydro-3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptonate 7-phosphate,N-(5-Phospho-D-ribosyl)anthranilate,1-(2-Carboxyphenylamino)-1-deoxy-D-ribulose 5-phosphate,2-Benzylmalic acid,3-Hydroxybenzoate,5-O-(1-Carboxyvinyl)-3-phosphoshikimate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan biosynthesis pathway. This identification is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The GOT2 and GOT1 genes are involved in the conversion of aspartate to oxaloacetate, which is a precursor for the biosynthesis of these aromatic amino acids. The IL4I1 gene, on the other hand, is involved in the catabolism of tryptophan. The altered compounds, such as 2-Dehydro-3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptonate 7-phosphate, N-(5-Phospho-D-ribosyl)anthranilate, and 1-(2-Carboxyphenylamino)-1-deoxy-D-ribulose 5-phosphate, are intermediates in the phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan biosynthesis pathway. The presence of 2-Benzylmalic acid and 3-Hydroxybenzoate suggests that there may be disruptions in the metabolism of these amino acids. The 5-O-(1-Carboxyvinyl)-3-phosphoshikimate is a key intermediate in the shikimate pathway, which leads to the biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids. The genes NDST4, EXTL1, EXT1, and B4GALT7 are all directly involved in the biosynthesis of heparan sulfate or heparin. NDST4 is a N-deacetylase/N-sulfotransferase that modifies heparan sulfate, EXTL1 and EXT1 are involved in the synthesis of heparan sulfate chains, and B4GALT7 is a galactosyltransferase that adds a galactose to the growing heparan sulfate chain. Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate and 3'-Phosphoadenylyl sulfate are involved in the biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and heparin. [Protein]-L-serine is a precursor for the synthesis of glycosaminoglycans, and Acetate is a metabolite involved in energy production, which could impact the energy-intensive process of glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis. Therefore, the data suggest that the Glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis - heparan sulfate/heparin pathway is significantly affected in the experiment.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Tryptophan metabolism pathway. This is evident from the altered genes, AOX1 and KMO, which are known to be involved in this pathway. AOX1, or aldehyde oxidase 1, is an enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of various aldehydes, including those derived from tryptophan metabolism. KMO, or kynurenine 3-monooxygenase, is another enzyme in the tryptophan metabolism pathway that converts kynurenine to 3-hydroxykynurenine.

Furthermore, the list of altered compounds also supports this conclusion. Many of these compounds, such as L-Tryptophan, Indole, 5-Hydroxyindoleacetate, and 5-Hydroxyindolepyruvate, are direct intermediates or products of the tryptophan metabolism pathway. Others, like 2-Aminomuconate semialdehyde, 2-Amino-3-carboxymuconate semialdehyde, and 2-Oxoadipate, are downstream products of this pathway. The presence of these compounds indicates that the tryptophan metabolism pathway is indeed active and altered under the conditions of this experiment.

List of compounds : <<< GMP,Inosine,N6-(1,2-Dicarboxyethyl)-AMP,5-Phospho-alpha-D-ribose 1-diphosphate,dCDP,XDP,CTP,Deoxyadenosine,ADP,Thymidine,UMP,ITP,Deoxyuridine,L-Glutamine,Deoxyinosine,UDP >>>

The experiment revealed alterations in genes ASMTL, AMPD2, ADSS2, and PNP, along with various compounds including GMP, Inosine, N6-(1,2-Dicarboxyethyl)-AMP, 5-Phospho-alpha-D-ribose 1-diphosphate, dCDP, XDP, CTP, Deoxyadenosine, ADP, Thymidine, UMP, ITP, Deoxyuridine, L-Glutamine, Deoxyinosine, and UDP. These findings point towards the involvement of the Nucleotide metabolism pathway.

ASMTL and PNP are involved in purine metabolism, a sub-pathway of nucleotide metabolism. AMPD2 and ADSS2 are involved in pyrimidine metabolism, another sub-pathway. The altered compounds, such as GMP, Inosine, and UMP, are intermediates in these sub-pathways, further supporting the identification of the nucleotide metabolism pathway. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Thiamine metabolism, based on the alterations observed in both genes and compounds. The genes ALPI, ACP1, ALPP, and ALPL are involved in alkaline phosphatase activity, which is crucial in the release of free thiamine from its phosphorylated forms. The AK family genes (AK8, AK2, AK7, AK4) encode Adenylate Kinases, enzymes that participate in adenosine nucleotide metabolism and can interact with thiamin-containing compounds. NFS1 and TPK1 are associated with iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis, which plays a role in thiamine-dependent enzymes.

The compound alterations further support the involvement of Thiamine metabolism. The presence of compounds such as Thiamine aldehyde, Thiamin diphosphate, Thiamin triphosphate, Thiamine acetic acid, and Thiamine indicate a disruption in Thiamine synthesis and metabolism. This conclusion is based on the significantly altered genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes SELENOI, PCYT1A, CEPT1, CHPT1, PCYT1B, and PCYT2 are involved in the regulation of phospholipid metabolism, which is closely related to phosphonate and phosphinate metabolism.

The presence of numerous phosphonate and phosphinate compounds such as Pyruvate, Phosphonoacetate, Diacylglyceryl-2-aminoethylphosphonate, Hydroxymethylphosphonate, Methylphosphonate, and others, further supports the involvement of this pathway. The analysis of the provided genes (PMM1, PFKFB4) and compounds (Oligouronide with 4-deoxy-alpha-L-erythro-hex-4-enopyranuronosyl group, alpha-D-Glucose, GDP-6-deoxy-D-talose, (S)-Lactate, L-Fuculose, D-Allulose 6-phosphate, L-Rhamnulose, D-Mannose, ADP-mannose, GDP-6-deoxy-D-mannose, D-Fructose 1-phosphate, Sorbose 1-phosphate, D-Glyceraldehyde, D-Allose, Sorbitol 6-phosphate, D-Mannose 6-phosphate, beta-D-Fructose 2-phosphate, Mannitol, L-Sorbose, D-Mannitol 1-phosphate, D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate, beta-D-Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate) indicates that the fructose and mannose metabolism pathway is involved in the specific condition.

PMM1 encodes phosphomannomutase, which converts D-mannose-6-phosphate to D-mannose-1-phosphate in the fructose and mannose metabolism pathway. PFKFB4 is a 6-phosphofructo-2-kinase/fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase that regulates the glycolytic pathway by controlling the levels of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, a potent allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK1) that catalyzes the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. The presence of D-mannose, D-mannose 6-phosphate, and D-mannitol 1-phosphate in the list of compounds also supports the involvement of the fructose and mannose metabolism pathway in the specific condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Arginine biosynthesis pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alterations in multiple genes directly involved in this pathway, such as ARG2, NAGS, ASS1, ASL, and ARG1. Similarly, the altered compounds, including 1-Alkenyl-2-acylglycerol, sn-Glycero-3-phosphocholine, 1-(1-Alkenyl)-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine, and others, are key intermediates or end products in the ether lipid metabolism pathway. These findings suggest that the observed condition may be related to dysregulation or disruption of ether lipid metabolism.

The comparison between the two conditions led to the identification of the Vitamin B6 metabolism pathway as being significantly altered. This is supported by the changes in genes and compounds associated with this pathway. PNPO, PSAT1, PDXK, and PDXP are all genes involved in the metabolism of Vitamin B6. PNPO is involved in the conversion of pyridoxamine 5'-phosphate to pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, a coenzyme form of Vitamin B6. PSAT1 is involved in the biosynthesis of Vitamin B6 from 3-hydroxy-2-methylpyridine-5-carboxylate. PDXK and PDXP are involved in the conversion of pyridoxine to pyridoxal 5'-phosphate. The observed alterations in the levels of pyridoxal phosphate, 3-Hydroxy-2-methylpyridine-5-carboxylate, 2-(Acetamidomethylene)succinate, and Glycolaldehyde, which are all intermediates or products of the Vitamin B6 metabolism pathway, further support the identification of this pathway as being involved in the condition.

The identified metabolic pathway is Ascorbate and aldarate metabolism. This pathway is characterized by the interconversion of various aldarate sugars, including uronates, galactonates, and glucuronates. The altered genes, such as UGT1A8, UGT2B7, UGT1A7, and UGDH, encode enzymes involved in the glucuronidation process, which is a key step in this pathway. Additionally, the altered compounds, including D-Galacturonate, UDP-glucuronate, and UDP-D-galacturonate, are direct participants in this metabolic pathway. The presence of ALDH9A1, ALDH1B1, and ALDH3A2, which are involved in aldehyde metabolism, also supports the involvement of the Ascorbate and aldarate metabolism pathway, as aldehydes are intermediate products in this pathway.

List of compounds : <<< Pimeloyl-[acyl-carrier protein],Tetranorbiotin,Biocytin,Biotin sulfoxide,7,8-Diaminononanoate,Pimeloyl-[acyl-carrier protein] methyl ester,Urea,Bisnorbiotin,3-Hydroxypimeloyl-[acp] methyl ester,Pimelate,Biotin,Enoylglutaryl-[acp] methyl ester,Malonyl-[acyl-carrier protein],Dethiobiotin,Biotin sulfone,3-Ketopimeloyl-[acp] methyl ester,8-Amino-7-oxononanoate,3-Hydroxyglutaryl-[acp] methyl ester,Long-chain acyl-[acyl-carrier protein],Glutaryl-[acp] methyl ester,Biotinyl-5'-AMP >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Biotin metabolism. This is supported by the alteration of several genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. The genes OXSM and BTD are known to play crucial roles in biotin metabolism. OXSM encodes the enzyme 7,8-diaminopelargonic acid synthase, which is involved in the final step of biotin biosynthesis. BTD, on the other hand, encodes biotinidase, the enzyme responsible for recycling biotin. The altered compounds, including Pimeloyl-[acyl-carrier protein], Biocytin, Biotin sulfoxide, and Biotinyl-5'-AMP, are intermediates or derivatives in the biotin metabolism pathway. Therefore, the collective alteration of these genes and compounds suggests that the Biotin metabolism pathway is significantly affected in the compared conditions.

This pathway is primarily involved in the metabolism of vitamin C (ascorbate) and its derivatives (aldarates). The genes UGT1A4, UGT1A8, and UGT2B4, which are involved in the glucuronidation of various compounds, suggest an involvement in the metabolism of ascorbate and its derivatives. The presence of compounds such as L-Ascorbate 6-phosphate, Dehydroascorbate, and Ascorbate directly implicates this pathway. The ALDH2 gene, which encodes an enzyme involved in the metabolism of aldehydes, may also play a role in this pathway, particularly in the metabolism of aldarates. The presence of compounds such as D-Arabinono-1,4-lactone, L-Galactono-1,4-lactone, and Dehydro-D-arabinono-1,4-lactone further supports this conclusion.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Alanine, Aspartate, and Glutamate Metabolism pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alterations in several genes and compounds associated with this pathway. Genes such as GPT2, GOT2, GLS, GPT, and GFPT1 are directly involved in this pathway, regulating the conversion of amino acids like L-Alanine, L-Aspartate, and L-Glutamine. The presence of compounds like L-Alanine, L-Aspartate, L-Glutamine, Ammonia, Pyruvate, and 2-Oxoglutarate further strengthens this identification. Additionally, other genes like IL4I1, NAT8L, ADSS2, FOLH1, and ALDH5A1, along with compounds like N-Acetylaspartylglutamate, 2-Oxosuccinamate, and 2-Oxoglutaramate, are indirectly related to this pathway, supporting its involvement in the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis - heparan sulfate / heparin pathway. This conclusion is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The genes B3GAT3, NDST3, EXT2, EXTL1, HS2ST1, XYLT2, and HS6ST3 are all involved in the biosynthesis of heparan sulfate and heparin, which are complex carbohydrates found in the extracellular matrix. The presence of [Protein]-L-serine, a precursor in this pathway, further supports this identification. Additionally, the compounds Acetate and Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate are known to regulate various steps in this pathway. Lastly, the presence of 3'-Phosphoadenylyl sulfate, a sulfate donor in the sulfation steps of this pathway, provides additional evidence for the involvement of this pathway in the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Vitamin B6 metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations in genes PDXK, PSAT1, PNPO, and PHOSPHO2, which are all involved in different steps of this pathway. PDXK is responsible for the synthesis of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, while PSAT1 and PNPO are involved in serine biosynthesis and tryptophan degradation, respectively, both of which are closely linked to vitamin B6 metabolism. PHOSPHO2 encodes a phosphatase that plays a role in maintaining intracellular pyridoxal 5'-phosphate levels. The altered compounds, including various forms of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine, pyridoxine phosphate, pyridoxamine phosphate, and pyridoxolactone), as well as intermediates in related pathways (serine and glutamine metabolism), further support this conclusion.

The experiment identified the Alanine, Aspartate and Glutamate Metabolism pathway as being significantly altered. This pathway involves the interconversion of these three amino acids, which are essential for protein synthesis and nitrogen metabolism. The altered genes, including ADSS1, GAD1, RIMKLB, NAT8L, GLUD1, GLS, and others, are directly involved in this pathway. For instance, GAD1 encodes glutamic acid decarboxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to GABA, and GLUD1 encodes glutamate dehydrogenase, which catalyzes the reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate. The altered compounds, 5-Phosphoribosylamine and beta-Citryl-L-glutamate, are intermediates in this pathway, further supporting the involvement of this pathway in the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Porphyrin metabolism pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alteration of multiple genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. Genes such as COX10, COX15, UROD, and ALAD are known to play crucial roles in porphyrin biosynthesis and metabolism. The altered compounds, including Uroporphyrinogen III, Precorrin 3B, and Bilirubin, are intermediates and end products in the Porphyrin metabolism pathway. Additionally, the presence of Hemoglobin and Cytochrome a, both of which contain heme, a product of porphyrin metabolism, further supports this identification. Therefore, the data suggest that the Porphyrin metabolism pathway is significantly affected in the compared conditions.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is fatty acid degradation. This is supported by the alterations observed in several genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes ALDH1B1, ADH6, ACADVL, ACSL4, and EHHADH are all involved in fatty acid metabolism. ALDH1B1 and ADH6 are associated with the oxidation of alcohols and aldehydes, steps in fatty acid degradation. ACADVL and EHHADH are involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, a process that breaks down fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. ACSL4 activates long-chain fatty acids for beta-oxidation. The altered compounds, including (S)-Hydroxydecanoyl-CoA, 3-Oxohexanoyl-CoA, and 3-Oxodecanoyl-CoA, are intermediates in the beta-oxidation pathway, further supporting the identification of fatty acid degradation as the affected pathway.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Valine, Leucine and Isoleucine Biosynthesis pathway. This is supported by the alterations in the genes SDS, SDSL, BCAT2, and BCAT1, which are directly involved in this pathway. SDS and SDSL encode subunits of the acetohydroxyacid synthase complex, the first committed step in the biosynthesis of these branched-chain amino acids. BCAT2 and BCAT1 encode branched-chain amino acid transaminases, which catalyze the final step in the biosynthesis of valine and the initial step in the catabolism of all three branched-chain amino acids. The altered compounds, including (R)-3-Hydroxy-3-methyl-2-oxopentanoate, (S)-2-Acetolactate, and L-Valine, are intermediates or end products of this pathway, further supporting the involvement of this pathway in the observed condition.

List of compounds : <<< H+,H+,H+,NAD+ >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Oxidative Phosphorylation, a process that occurs in the inner mitochondrial membrane to generate ATP. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in genes such as COX6A2, MT-CYB, COX7A2, ATP5F1E, NDUFB2, MT-CO1, NDUFB11, COX10, MT-CO3, ATP4A, UQCRFS1, NDUFB7, NDUFA3, and NDUFV2, which are all key components of the electron transport chain and ATP synthase complexes in oxidative phosphorylation. Moreover, the altered compounds H+ and NAD+ are directly involved in this pathway. Protons (H+) are pumped across the membrane to create a proton gradient, which drives ATP synthesis, and NAD+ is a coenzyme that accepts electrons during the electron transport chain, ultimately contributing to the generation of ATP. Therefore, the observed alterations in these genes and compounds strongly suggest a role for oxidative phosphorylation in the condition under investigation.

List of genes : <<< ALDH1B1,LPIN2,MGLL,GPAT4,PLPP2,AGPAT2,PNLIPRP2,DGKZ >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Glycerolipid metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations observed in several genes and compounds associated with it. The genes ALDH1B1, MGLL, GPAT4, AGPAT2, and DGKZ are directly involved in the synthesis and degradation of glycerolipids. The altered compounds, including Glycerol, 1-Acyl-sn-glycerol 3-phosphate, Fatty acid, and Glycerophosphoglycoglycerolipid, are key intermediates in this pathway. The presence of 1,2-Diacyl-3-alpha-D-glucosyl-sn-glycerol and 1,2-Diacyl-3-beta-D-galactosyl-sn-glycerol suggest the involvement of glycerolipid glycosylation. Therefore, the observed changes in genes and compounds strongly support the implication of the Glycerolipid metabolism pathway in the studied condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Biosynthesis of Unsaturated Fatty Acids. This conclusion aligns with the alterations observed in genes and compounds. The gene list includes ELOVL3, ELOVL1, ELOVL5, HACD1, ACOT4, ACOX3, ACOX1, ACOT2, and ACAA1, which are all known to be involved in the biosynthesis and degradation of unsaturated fatty acids. The compound list also supports this finding, as it includes various unsaturated fatty acids and their intermediate forms, such as (11Z,14Z,17Z)-Icosatrienoyl-CoA, (5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z,17Z)-Icosapentaenoyl-CoA, and (11Z,14Z,17Z,20Z)-Hexacosatetraenoyl-CoA, among others. The presence of these compounds indicates active biosynthesis and metabolism of unsaturated fatty acids.

List of compounds : <<< Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate,3'-Phosphoadenylyl sulfate,Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate >>>

The experiment identified the Glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis - chondroitin sulfate / dermatan sulfate pathway as the affected metabolic pathway. This is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The genes B3GAT3, DSE, CHST15, CHSY3, DSEL, XYLT1, and CSGALNACT1 are all directly involved in the synthesis of chondroitin sulfate and dermatan sulfate, which are key components of this pathway. The compounds Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate and 3'-Phosphoadenylyl sulfate are crucial cofactors in the sulfation reactions required for the biosynthesis of these glycosaminoglycans. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Glycosaminoglycan biosynthesis - chondroitin sulfate / dermatan sulfate pathway is affected in the specific condition under study.

List of genes : <<< ADO,FMO1,GAD2,GADL1,FMO5,GGT5,GGT1,FMO4,FMO2,CSAD,BAAT >>>
List of compounds : <<< Acetyl-CoA,Acetyl phosphate,Cysteamine,N-Phosphotaurocyamine,Acetaldehyde,2-Hydroxyethanesulfonate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Taurine and Hypotaurine Metabolism pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alterations in genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes ADO, FMO1, FMO5, FMO4, FMO2, CSAD, and BAAT are all involved in the metabolism of taurine and hypotaurine. The compound N-Phosphotaurocyamine is a direct intermediate in this pathway, while Cysteamine is a precursor to taurine synthesis. The presence of Acetyl-CoA and Acetaldehyde may suggest a link with other pathways, but their role in this context is likely related to the conversion of cysteamine to hypotaurine. The altered levels of 2-Hydroxyethanesulfonate, a byproduct of taurine catabolism, further supports the involvement of this pathway.

List of genes : <<< FDPS,NUS1,IDI2,ICMT,IDI1,CHURC1-FNTB >>>
List of compounds : <<< (R)-5-Diphosphomevalonate,Geranylgeranyl diphosphate,trans-Anhydromevalonate phosphate,Acetoacetyl-CoA,all-trans-Hexaprenyl diphosphate,(R)-Mevalonate,Isopentenyl phosphate,all-trans-Heptaprenyl diphosphate,(R)-Mevalonate 3,5-bisphosphate,all-trans-Nonaprenyl diphosphate,1-Deoxy-D-xylulose 5-phosphate,(2E,6E)-Farnesol,2-trans,6-trans-Farnesal,2-cis,6-cis-Farnesyl diphosphate,2-C-Methyl-D-erythritol 4-phosphate,cis-1,4-Polyisoprene,trans,octacis-Decaprenyl diphosphate,S-Farnesyl protein,(R)-Mevalonate 3-phosphate,Acetyl-CoA,trans,trans-Farnesyl phosphate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Terpenoid backbone biosynthesis. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in genes such as FDPS, NUS1, IDI2, ICMT, IDI1, and CHURC1-FNTB, which are all known to be involved in this pathway. The changes in these genes directly impact the production of terpenoids, which are a large and diverse class of organic compounds produced by a variety of organisms.

The list of altered compounds further supports this finding. Compounds such as (R)-5-Diphosphomevalonate, Geranylgeranyl diphosphate, and Isopentenyl phosphate are key intermediates in the Terpenoid backbone biosynthesis pathway. Additionally, the presence of prenyl diphosphates like Heptaprenyl diphosphate and Decaprenyl diphosphate, as well as the final products Farnesol, Farnesal, and Farnesyl diphosphate, indicate active terpenoid synthesis. Therefore, the data suggest that alterations in the Terpenoid backbone biosynthesis pathway are associated with the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< MAT1A,ACY1,PGAM2,BCAT2,TPI1,ABHD14A-ACY1,PFKM,CTH,ARG1,ASNS,TALDO1,MAT2A,ACO2,MTR,GPT >>>
List of compounds : <<< D-Erythrose 4-phosphate,Glycerone phosphate,L-Glutamate 5-semialdehyde,3-Dehydroquinate,D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate,1-(5-Phospho-D-ribosyl)-ATP,(S)-2-Acetolactate,S-Sulfo-L-cysteine,L-Proline,Homoisocitrate,Isocitrate,2,3,4,5-Tetrahydrodipicolinate,L-Lysine,LysW-L-glutamate,S-Adenosyl-L-methionine,3-Dehydroshikimate,L-2-Aminoadipate,S-Adenosyl-L-homocysteine,L-Aspartate 4-semialdehyde,L-Cystathionine,(S)-1-Pyrroline-5-carboxylate,D-Fructose 6-phosphate,(2R,3S)-3-Isopropylmalate,2-Oxoglutarate,3-(4-Hydroxyphenyl)pyruvate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified from the experiment is the "Biosynthesis of amino acids." This pathway was inferred based on the alterations in multiple genes and compounds associated with amino acid metabolism. Genes such as MAT1A, MAT2A, MTR, and CTH are involved in the synthesis of methionine, arginine, and cysteine, respectively. The presence of intermediate compounds like S-Adenosyl-L-methionine, L-Cystathionine, and L-Aspartate 4-semialdehyde further supports this pathway. Additionally, the altered genes BCAT2, ASNS, and ACO2, which are involved in the synthesis of branched-chain amino acids, asparagine, and citrate, respectively, and the presence of compounds such as L-Glutamate 5-semialdehyde and Homoisocitrate, suggest the involvement of this pathway. Therefore, the data suggest a significant role of oxidative phosphorylation in the observed condition.

The altered genes, including STT3A, ALG2, ALG6, DPM3, and MOGS, are all key enzymes in this pathway. The genes AOC2 and FAHD1 are involved in the metabolism of tyrosine to produce various compounds, including melanin and certain neurotransmitters. MAOA, on the other hand, is involved in the degradation of neurotransmitters derived from tyrosine. The compounds Pyruvate and 3-Amino-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)propanoate (L-DOPA) are intermediates in the Tyrosine metabolism pathway, while Eumelanin and 2,5-Dihydroxybenzoate are end products. The alteration of these genes and compounds suggests a disruption in the Tyrosine metabolism pathway, making it a likely candidate for the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Glutathione metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alteration of several genes directly involved in glutathione metabolism, including GPX2, GPX3, GPX5, GPX6, GSTT1, GSTT2B, and PRDX6. These genes encode for enzymes such as glutathione peroxidases and glutathione S-transferases, which are key players in the detoxification of reactive oxygen species and xenobiotics through the reduction of glutathione. The alterations in compounds such as Glycine, NADP+, NADPH, and S-Substituted N-acetyl-L-cysteine further support this, as these compounds are essential cofactors or precursors in glutathione metabolism. The identification of Tryparedoxin and Tryparedoxin disulfide, which are involved in a similar redox system in trypanosomatids, may suggest potential crosstalk or compensation mechanisms between the two systems.

The observed changes in (R)-(Homo)2-citrate, a compound involved in energy metabolism, and other intermediates suggest a possible link between energy metabolism and cofactor biosynthesis in the specific condition under investigation.

The genes GLYCTK, GLDC, GNMT, SARDH, and SHMT2 are directly involved in this pathway, with GLYCTK and GLDC involved in glycine metabolism, GNMT in methionine metabolism interconnected with glycine, serine, and threonine metabolism, SARDH in serine metabolism, and SHMT2 in serine and one-carbon metabolism. The experiment identified the Galactose metabolism pathway as the primary pathway affected. This is supported by the alteration of several genes directly involved in this pathway. B4GALT2 and LALBA are involved in the synthesis of lactose, a primary disaccharide in galactose metabolism. GAA encodes for lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of glycogen and glycogen-derived oligosaccharides to glucose, which can then be metabolized to galactose. The alteration of PFKM, GCK, HKDC1, and HK1, which are involved in glycolysis, further supports this, as glucose and galactose share this pathway. The altered compounds, including D-Mannose, D-Galactose, and UDP-glucose, are all intermediates or byproducts of the galactose metabolism pathway.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Vitamin B6 metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in the genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes PDXK, PHOSPHO2, PDXP, and PSAT1 are involved in the metabolism of Vitamin B6, with PDXK and PDXP encoding pyridoxal kinase and pyridoxine 5'-phosphate oxidase respectively, which are essential for the conversion of Vitamin B6 to its active form, pyridoxal phosphate. The compounds Isopyridoxal, Pyridoxal phosphate, Pyridoxamine, and 5-Pyridoxolactone are intermediates or derivatives of Vitamin B6, further supporting the involvement of this pathway. These genes are key regulators of fructose metabolism, converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (PFKP, PFKL) and vice versa (FBP1, FBP2). The alterations in the levels of compounds such as D-Fructose 2-phosphate, L-Rhamnose, and D-Glyceraldehyde further support this, as these are intermediates in the fructose and mannose metabolism pathway. The presence of L-Fucose 1-phosphate and L-Rhamnofuranose could suggest a link to related pathways such as fructose and mannose degradation and L-fucose metabolism.

Based on the provided list of genes and compounds, the metabolic pathway involved is the "Metabolism of xenobiotics by cytochrome P450". This pathway is primarily responsible for the detoxification of a wide variety of foreign chemical substances, known as xenobiotics, in the body. The genes listed, such as CYP2A13, CYP1A1, CYP2S1, CYP2C9, and others, are all members of the cytochrome P450 superfamily, which are known to encode enzymes involved in this pathway. These enzymes catalyze the oxidation, reduction, and hydroxylation reactions of the listed compounds, such as 1-Nitronaphthalene-5,6-oxide, Aflatoxin M1, and Benzo[a]pyrene-7,8-dihydrodiol, thereby facilitating their elimination from the body. The alterations in these genes and compounds suggest changes in this metabolic pathway, which could have implications for the body's ability to detoxify xenobiotics.

OGDH is involved in the oxidative decarboxylation of 2-oxoglutarate, PDHA2 is a component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, and AADAT is involved in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Vitamin B6 metabolism. This conclusion is based on the alteration of genes PHOSPHO2, PNPO, PDXK, and AOX1, which are all directly involved in Vitamin B6 metabolism. PHOSPHO2 encodes an enzyme that converts pyridoxine to pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of Vitamin B6. PNPO is involved in the conversion of pyridoxamine phosphate to pyridoxal phosphate. PDXK is responsible for the phosphorylation of pyridoxine and pyridoxal to their respective phosphate forms. AOX1 encodes an aldehyde oxidase that can oxidize pyridoxal to pyridoxate. Furthermore, the altered compounds, such as Pyridoxine, Pyridoxate, Pyridoxine phosphate, Pyridoxal phosphate, Pyridoxamine phosphate, and Succinate semialdehyde, are all intermediates or byproducts in the Vitamin B6 metabolism pathway. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Oxidative Phosphorylation. This conclusion is supported by the altered genes and compounds. The genes listed, such as NDUFA5, NDUFB7, NDUFS6, and NDUFA12, are subunits of Complex I in the electron transport chain, a crucial component of Oxidative Phosphorylation. SDHA and COX7B2 are involved in Complex II and Complex IV, respectively, further implicating this pathway. The compounds H+, NAD+, ADP, ATP, and Oxygen are all key players in Oxidative Phosphorylation, where protons (H+) are pumped across a membrane to generate a proton motive force, which is then used to synthesize ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate. The presence of Fumarate, a TCA cycle intermediate, suggests a link between this pathway and the Krebs cycle, which feeds into Oxidative Phosphorylation.

The analysis of the altered genes and compounds indicates that the Pyruvate metabolism pathway is significantly involved in the condition. The genes ADH4, PKM, LDHA, and DLAT are directly associated with this pathway. ADH4 and LDHA are involved in the conversion of alcohol and lactate to acetaldehyde and pyruvate, respectively. PKM is a key enzyme in the final step of glycolysis, which produces pyruvate. DLAT is a component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The altered compounds, such as acetyl phosphate, acetaldehyde, lactate, and succinate, are also intermediates or products of the Pyruvate metabolism pathway. Additionally, the presence of compounds like 2-(alpha-Hydroxyethyl)thiamine diphosphate (a derivative of Thiamin diphosphate, a cofactor for pyruvate decarboxylase) and N6-(lipoyl)lysine (a component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex) further supports the involvement of this pathway.

OXSM and MECR are involved in the final steps of fatty acid elongation, ACSL5, ACSL3, and ACSL6 are long-chain fatty acid-CoA ligases that activate fatty acids for beta-oxidation or synthesis, and ACACB is the beta-subunit of acetyl-CoA carboxylase, a key enzyme in fatty acid biosynthesis. The compounds (3R)-3-Hydroxypalmitoyl-[acyl-carrier protein] and Malonyl-CoA are also directly involved in fatty acid biosynthesis, with the former being an intermediate in the elongation process and the latter being the initial substrate for the pathway. Therefore, the observed alterations in these genes and compounds suggest that fatty acid biosynthesis is affected in the studied condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations observed in several genes and compounds associated with it. The genes HOGA1, HAO2, HAO1, MMUT, AGXT, DLD, and CAT are directly involved in this pathway, which involves the conversion of isocitrate to succinate, bypassing the citrate synthase (CS) and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reactions of the citric acid cycle. The altered compounds, such as Acetyl-CoA, (S)-Malate, Formyl-CoA, and D-Ribulose 1-phosphate, are intermediates or substrates in this pathway, further supporting its involvement. The Glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism is particularly active in conditions where carbohydrates are scarce and lipids are the primary source of carbon, which may be the case in the specific conditions compared in this experiment.

The analysis of the provided data suggests that the altered genes and compounds are associated with the Arachidonic acid metabolism pathway. This pathway is involved in the conversion of arachidonic acid into various eicosanoids, which are signaling molecules involved in inflammation, immune response, and other physiological processes. The genes PRXL2B, PLA2G4C, PLA2G4E, PLA2G4D, and CYP2C19 are all involved in the metabolism of arachidonic acid, and their alterations would likely affect the production and balance of eicosanoids. The altered compounds, such as Leukotriene B4, Prostaglandin F2alpha, Thromboxane A2, and various hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids (HETEs) and epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs), are all products of arachidonic acid metabolism, further supporting the involvement of this pathway in the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the "Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan biosynthesis" pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in the genes and compounds. The gene GOT1 encodes a cytosolic aspartate aminotransferase, which is involved in the biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids, including phenylalanine and tyrosine. The gene PAH encodes phenylalanine hydroxylase, an enzyme that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. The gene TAT encodes tyrosine aminotransferase, which catalyzes the conversion of tyrosine to 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate. The altered compounds, L-Tyrosine, 3-Hydroxybenzoate, 1-(2-Carboxyphenylamino)-1-deoxy-D-ribulose 5-phosphate, and Anthranilate, are all intermediates or products of this pathway, further supporting the identification of this metabolic pathway.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Biosynthesis of nucleotide sugars. This pathway involves the conversion of simple sugars into nucleotide-activated sugars, which are crucial for the biosynthesis of glycoconjugates such as glycoproteins and glycolipids. The altered genes GFUS, GMPPB, GFPT1, GNPNAT1, MPI, and GALE are all involved in this pathway. GFUS and GMPPB are involved in the synthesis of GDP-mannose, a key nucleotide sugar, while GFPT1, MPI, and GALE are involved in the synthesis of UDP-glucose and UDP-Galactose, precursors for other nucleotide sugars. The altered compounds, including D-Fructose 6-phosphate, N-Acetyl-D-glucosamine, and various nucleotide sugars, further support this pathway's involvement. The changes in these genes and compounds suggest that the Biosynthesis of nucleotide sugars pathway is critical for the condition under investigation.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Cysteine and Methionine metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in several genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The gene PHGDH, which encodes an enzyme involved in serine biosynthesis, a precursor for cysteine synthesis, was found to be altered. Additionally, the genes CBS and BHMT, which are involved in the transsulfuration pathway and methionine cycle respectively, both crucial components of cysteine and methionine metabolism, were also altered. The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the 2-Oxocarboxylic acid metabolism. This pathway involves the breakdown and conversion of 2-oxocarboxylic acids, also known as alpha-keto acids. ACO2 encodes aconitase, which catalyzes the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate. The altered compounds, including Acetyl-CoA, L-2-Aminoadipate, and N6-Acetyl-L-lysine, are intermediates or products of the lysine degradation pathway. DBT is a key enzyme in the degradation of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), including valine. BCAT2 is responsible for the initial step in BCAA catabolism, converting valine to alpha-ketoisocaproate. The altered compounds, such as L-Valine, (S)-Methylmalonate semialdehyde, and (2S,3S)-3-Hydroxy-2-methylbutanoyl-CoA, are also intermediates in this pathway. The genes SUCLA2, SUCLG1, SUCLG2, MDH2, MDH1, IDH2, IDH3G, IDH3A, IDH1, CS, DLD, DLST, and SDHA, SDHB, SDHC, SDHD are involved in the TCA cycle. The genes PAH (Phenylalanine Hydroxylase) and IL4I1 (Interleukin 4 Induced 1) are both involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine. IL4I1, on the other hand, is involved in the alternative pathway of phenylalanine metabolism, particularly during immune responses. The altered compounds, which include phenylalanine and its various metabolites such as phenylacetic acid, phenyllactate, and phenylpyruvate, further support the involvement of the phenylalanine metabolism pathway. This pathway involves the metabolism of nicotinate (niacin) and nicotinamide (a form of vitamin B3) into NAD+ and NADP+, coenzymes essential for cellular energy metabolism and other cellular functions. SIRT4, NMNAT1, and NT5C are involved in NAD+ metabolism, while BST1, NMRK2, and NT5E are associated with nicotinamide metabolism. The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Taurine and hypotaurine metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in several genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. The genes FMO3, CDO1, and ADO are known to play crucial roles in this pathway. FMO3 is involved in the oxidation of taurine, CDO1 is responsible for the conversion of cysteine to cysteine sulfinic acid, and ADO is involved in polyamine metabolism, which can indirectly affect taurine metabolism. The compounds Taurine, Hypotaurine, N-Phosphotaurocyamine, 5-L-Glutamyl-taurine, L-Glutamate, and Acetyl-CoA are direct intermediates or products of this pathway. The presence of Sulfite, Sulfoacetaldehyde, 3-Sulfino-L-alanine, and 2-Hydroxyethanesulfonate suggests potential crosstalk with sulfur metabolism, which is closely linked to taurine metabolism. Therefore, the alterations in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Taurine and hypotaurine metabolism pathway is significantly affected in the condition under study.

GYS1 and GYG1 are involved in glycogen synthesis, while AMY1A, MGAM2, and PYGM are involved in starch and glycogen breakdown. G6PC3 and GCK are involved in glucose metabolism, which is a key intermediate in this pathway. The altered compounds, including ADP-glucose, D-Glucose, Levan, and alpha,alpha'-Trehalose 6-phosphate, are all intermediates or products of this pathway, further supporting its involvement in the observed condition.

The genes FXN, FECH, PPOX, CPOX, HMBS, ALAS1, and ALAS2 are directly involved in porphyrin metabolism, which is responsible for the biosynthesis of heme, a critical component of hemoglobin. The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is "Pentose and glucuronate interconversions". This pathway involves the interconversion of pentose sugars and glucuronate, and it is closely linked with the metabolism of carbohydrates. The altered genes, including UGT1A5, UGT1A6, UGT2B28, UGT1A7, UGT1A8, UGT2A3, and AKR1B10, are all UDP-glucuronosyltransferases (UGTs) and aldo-keto reductases (AKRs) that play crucial roles in this pathway. These enzymes catalyze the conjugation of glucuronic acid to various substrates, including sugars and lipids. The altered compounds, such as 5-Dehydro-4-deoxy-D-glucuronate, L-Ribulose 5-phosphate, D-Arabitol, and D-Glucose 1-phosphate, are intermediates or products of this pathway. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Pentose and glucuronate interconversions pathway is involved in the specific condition under investigation.

The genes AK2, AK8, and ACP1 are involved in energy metabolism, which is closely linked to thiamine as it is a coenzyme in various energy-producing reactions. ALPI, although not directly involved in thiamine metabolism, can indirectly affect it through its role in lipid metabolism. The compounds Thiamin monophosphate, Thiamine, and its precursors 5-(2-Hydroxyethyl)-4-methylthiazole and 2-[(2R,5Z)-2-Carboxy-4-methylthiazol-5(2H)-ylidene]ethyl phosphate, as well as the Sulfur-carrier protein, are key intermediates in the thiamine biosynthesis pathway. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Porphyrin metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in genes such as BLVRA, CP, FXN, HMOX1, and HMBS, all of which are known to be involved in this pathway. The BLVRA gene encodes an enzyme that catalyzes a step in heme biosynthesis, while HMBS is involved in the synthesis of porphyrinogens. The CP gene encodes an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of protoporphyrinogen IX to protoporphyrin IX, a crucial step in heme biosynthesis. The FXN gene is involved in iron-sulfur cluster assembly, which is necessary for heme synthesis. The HMOX1 gene encodes an enzyme that degrades heme to biliverdin, which is then converted to bilirubin. The alterations in these genes suggest dysregulation in the Porphyrin metabolism pathway. Furthermore, the altered compounds, including Precorrin 8X, Coproporphyrin III, and Heme d1, are all intermediates in the Porphyrin metabolism pathway, providing additional evidence for the involvement of this pathway in the observed condition.

The genes PDSS2, CHURC1-FNTB, and GGPS1 are all involved in this pathway. PDSS2 encodes an enzyme in the mevalonate pathway that synthesizes isopentenyl diphosphate (IPP), a key precursor in terpenoid biosynthesis. CHURC1-FNTB is involved in the synthesis of geranylgeranyl diphosphate, which is derived from IPP and dimethylallyl diphosphate. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Fatty Acid Elongation pathway. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in the genes and compounds involved in this pathway. The genes ACAA2, ELOVL6, HACD3, and HADHB are all known to play crucial roles in fatty acid elongation. ACAA2 encodes an enzyme involved in the final step of fatty acid beta-oxidation, which is closely linked to fatty acid elongation. ELOVL6 is a key enzyme in elongating very long chain fatty acids. HACD3 is involved in the elongation of very long chain fatty acids and the synthesis of sphingolipids, while HADHB encodes a subunit of the mitochondrial trifunctional protein, which is involved in both beta-oxidation and the elongation of odd-chain fatty acids. The altered compounds, including various acyl-CoAs and long-chain fatty acids, are direct intermediates or products of the fatty acid elongation process, further supporting this conclusion.
